title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
description: Every integer > 1 is uniquely representable as a product of primes. The cornerstone of number theory.

meta.author: Euclid, Gauss (formalized in Lean 4 with Mathlib)

mathlibDependencies.description: Product of factors equals the number

overview.historicalContext: Known to Euclid, formally proved by Gauss in 1801. Primes are the 'atoms' of number theory.
overview.problemStatement:
**Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic**:

Every n > 1 has a unique prime factorization:
$$n = p_1^{a_1} \cdot p_2^{a_2} \cdots p_k^{a_k}$$
overview.proofStrategy: Existence by strong induction. Uniqueness via Euclid's Lemma (if p|ab then p|a or p|b).
keyInsights: Euclid's Lemma is key to uniqueness

conclusion.summary: Both existence and uniqueness of prime factorization are verified.
